[[File:Comedian_Dave_Willis.jpg|thumb|right|Painting of comedian Dave Willis by [[Henry Raeburn Dobson]], 1940 [[National Galleries of Scotland]]]]'''Dave Willis''' (Nom de Guerre of David Williams) (1895– 1 January 1973) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[comedian]] and [[actor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://artuk.org/discover/artworks/david-williams-18951973-comedian-nom-de-guerre-dave-willis-212256|title=David Williams (1895–1973), Comedian (Nom de Guerre Dave Willis)|website=artuk.org |accessdate=30 September 2017}}</ref><ref name=scottishtheatrearchive>{{cite web|url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/services/specialcollections/collectionsa-z/scottishtheatrearchive/stacollections/davewillis/|title=University of Glasgow|work=gla.ac.uk}}</ref> He was a major [[music hall]] star in the 1930s and the 1940s in [[Glasgow]], who came to prominence in [[pantomime]]. The actor [[Jerry Desmonde]] acted as a stooge to him.<ref>Donnelley, p. 208</ref> He made two films for [[Welwyn Studios]] co-starring with [[Patricia Kirkwood]] in the late 1930s. The 'Scottish Theatre Archive' describes how a "genial, slightly bemused style of comedy characterised his 'little' man style of comedy". One of his best known songs was "In my wee gas mask" about an [[Air Raid Precautions|ARP]] warden ("the nicest looking warden in the A.R.P").<ref name=scottishtheatrearchive/>
==Biography== He was born in Glasgow, the son of a butcher.<ref name="Herald 2Jan1973">{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NeE9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=TUgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2845%2C102160 |title=Dave Willis dies at 78 |work=The Glasgow Herald |date=2 January 1973 |page=9 |accessdate=30 September 2017}}</ref>
He had appeared in "Half-Past Eight" show at [[Theatre Royal, Glasgow|Theatre Royal]].<ref name="Herald 12Aug1949">{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rG5RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IjQNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3210%2C7742070 |title=Dave Willis Capers |work=The Glasgow Herald |date=12 August 1949 |page=7 |accessdate=30 September 2017}}</ref> In 1943 it ran for 32 weeks, the longest a show had run in Glasgow and a record that he still held at the time of his death.<ref name="Herald 2Jan1973"/>
He retired from the stage in 1950.<ref name="Herald 2Jan1973"/> A decade later he was back on stage.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Skw1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=CaYLAAAAIBAJ&pg=1902%2C6782415 |title=Dave Willis carries off the honours |work=The Glasgow Herald |date=21 February 1961 |page=9 |accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref> He died at his home in [[Peebles]] on 1 January 1973.<ref name="Herald 2Jan1973"/>
His son [[Denny Willis]] was also a music hall performer and incorporated a number of his father's routines into his act.<ref name=scottishtheatrearchive/>
